title: Terpenes - Cannabis Chemistry and Natural Medicine
author: marsresident / Van Kush Family
overview: Introduction to terpenes as the chemistry behind natural smells and medicines, with focus on cannabis terpenes and their effects

caryophyllene.significance: What dogs are trained to smell for marijuana detection
caryophyllene.not_illegal_because: Not similar to THC in structure
caryophyllene.fda_status: First cannabinoid approved as food additive by FDA

limonene.effect: Can affect mood when smoked or ingested
limonene.research: Further research likely to show limonoids are entire class of cannabinoids

myrcene.abundance: Most abundant terpene in hops (large portion of what makes beer)

terpene_classifications.ubiquity: Found in pretty much every plant

terpene_applications.natural_smells: Terpenes make up entire world of natural smells
terpene_applications.medicines: Terpenes make up entire world of natural medicines

quiz_questions.q: What is caryophyllene and why is it significant?
quiz_questions.a: Terpene used to train dogs to smell marijuana, attaches to CB1 receptor, first cannabinoid FDA approved as food additive
quiz_questions.explanation: Legal because not similar to THC structure despite being cannabinoid

quiz_questions.q: What does myrcene do in combination with THC?
quiz_questions.a: Helps THC cross blood-brain barrier, making less marijuana have more effect
quiz_questions.explanation: Also has direct opioid analgesic (pain killer) effects

quiz_questions.q: What is the best source of caryophyllene?
quiz_questions.a: Uziza leaf or Uziza Peppercorns - popular in Nigeria, related to pepper plant
quiz_questions.explanation: Not common in Europe since Middle Ages

quiz_questions.a: Entire world of natural smells and medicines - found in almost every plant
quiz_questions.explanation: From lemon peels to tree sap to cooking herbs to aromatherapy
